Comments_List: Learned many research techniques, how to develop better oral presentations and basically what lab to work for the next few years.
I've come closer to learning how to science!
I learned what lab I wanted to join. I was also exposed to new techniques and met more people working in my area.
New lab techniques and new research topics
I developed and practiced lab skills for biochemistry research.
The length of rotations are good, sometimes rotations talks get stressful when they overlap with heavy course-load.
I think ultimately, I like the six weeks format since although it didn't quite allow me to get much work done, it did offer enough time to learn a bit about my project and get familiar with the lab.
It would be nice to get PI comments on our rotation back before we select a lab.

I'm glad we had three rotations. I'm not sure if this is true, but it felt like the second rotation was much shorter than the rest and I feel like they should all be even. I also felt like not much organization went into the final rotation talk, which made the students feel like the talk wasn't very important. I also think an off rotation isn't always necessary as many students do have a very good idea about what they want to do, but I do agree that for some students it is valuable.
Professors in other departments do not realize that MB&B students are taking a higher course load.
Yes, the lab rotation experience in very important in grad school.
